Dialogue.Stage Direction: England, June, 1925. A servant in a white coat is strangled in the corridor, while a young woman who looks remarkably like Nyssa sleeps. Elsewhere in the house, someone has been tied up on a bed, and an Amazon Indian with a stretched lower lip sits reading a book.
Next day, at Cranleigh Halt, the station master waves off the Great Western train and goes back inside. Then the Tardis materialises on the station platform.

Dialogue.Line: I did say I wanted to stay with the crew for a while. You can stop trying to get me back to Heathrow.
You certainly know how to fly this crate, don't you.
What's the matter, old girl? Why this compulsion for planet Earth?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He turns the scanner on.

Dialogue.Line: It's interesting, isn't it. And no jet lag. Shall we go outside?
You think that wise, considering what we've just done to London?
Oh, that would have happened if we'd been there or not. All part of Earth's history.
Well, I'd like to take a look.
So what is a railway station?
Well, a place where one embarks and disembarks from compartments on wheels, drawn along these rails by a steam engine. Rarely on time.
You think so? As a boy I always wanted to drive one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A chauffeur is passing the time polishing the Rolls Royce. He goes to greet the Doctor as he walks through the gate.

Dialogue.Line: Good afternoon, sir. I'm Tanner, Lord Cranleigh's chauffeur.
Oh yes, sir. You are the Doctor?
May I ask what you're staring at?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tanner opens the passenger door.

Dialogue.Line: Please, sir, if you don't mind. The game's already started. His lordship won the toss and decided to bat first to give you time to get here. That train's always slate.
That's very thoughtful of his Lordship.
Er, yes, sir. But I do think we should hurry. His lordship is a first class bat, but I'm not quite sure how strong his support is this year.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tanner gives the trousered Nyssa a strange look, then salutes the Doctor. They all climb into the back of the vintage Rolls Royce UL6654 and are driven off.

Dialogue.Line: Now what? Where are we going?
It's out here on the platform.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Stationmaster shows the police constable the large blue obstruction on his railway platform.

Dialogue.Line: Here, what do you make of that, Constable?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lord Charles Cranleigh leaves the match and runs across the ground to meet the car as it comes down the lane.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, there you are, man, good. I'm Cranleigh. Didn't expect four of you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He stares at Nyssa as she steps out of the car.

Dialogue.Line: Good lord. Er, I'm so sorry. Do forgive me for staring. You look exactly like my fiancée. It's quite uncanny.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A cry of Howzat! from the match.

Dialogue.Line: How do you do. Well, you'd better pad up, Doctor. Got your gear?
Ah, I regret I have none.
No matter, I'll fix you up. We're taking a terrible thrashing. 54 for 8. I made a duck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charles leads the Doctor away, and the others follow.

Dialogue.Line: Smutty said he'd send a useful bat.
Smutty Thomas. Oh, don't you call him Smutty at Guys?
Er, no, as a matter of fact.
Oh, he was Smutty at school. Now, the wicket's very green, the ball's keeping low. Any good with the ball?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another batsman is given out. Cranleigh CC are 56 for 9 and the Doctor has been provided with pads and a bat.
The Doctor takes his position on the wicket.
He checks the fielding around him and takes his stance, then smashes the first delivery for four.
The Doctor continues to smack the ball all around the field. The score passes 144.
Over by the pavilion.

Dialogue.Line: Mother, may I introduce Tegan and Adric.
How do you do? What enchanting names.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lady Cranleigh and her companion stand.

Dialogue.Line: Forgive me, my dear, but you must be a Worcestershire Talbot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone say Hi to the splendid Moray Watson.

Dialogue.Line: Two peas in a pod. Positively two peas in a pod.
Forgive a pardonably curiosity, my dear, but where are you from?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes a single.

Dialogue.Line: Your Doctor substitute has made your score almost respectable, Charles.
Perfectly ripping performance. Much better player than Smutty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The batting side are now all out, and the Doctor is bowling. He takes a long run up and clean bowls the middle stump. Honestly. It's a wide camera shot and Peter really is that good.
Nyssa and Adric are baffled by the game. The Doctor bowls out another batsman.
44 for 7. Oh dear. And another one.
And again.
And again.
The umpire draws stumps. The match is over.

Dialogue.Line: Ripping performance, old boy. Come over to the house and meet the mater.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The car pulls up outside Buckhurst House, which could easily have been the inspiration for Agatha Christie's 1925, the Secret of Chimneys. The Amazon Indian watches them arrive from an upstairs window, then closes the shutters. Charles leads the Doctor in from the entrance hall.

Dialogue.Line: Mother, may I present the Doctor.
I'm sorry, Mother, but he'd like to remain incognito, and I think we should respect that after what he's done today.
Sir Robert Muir, the Chief Constable.
A superb innings, worthy of the master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks baffled.

Dialogue.Line: Are you able to stay for the ball, Doctor?
Yes, you must. I insist now, all of you.
We have one every year in aid of the Hospital for Sick Children.
I was just thinking how charming yours was.
Costumes are no problem. We keep a selection for last minute guests. I'm sure we can fix you up. Well, Doctor, how would you like to take a cocktail to your bath?
What do you do with a cocktail in a bath?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Upstairs, a snarling man struggles against his bonds.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Ann, my dear. Come and meet the hero of the day, and.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charles puts his arm around a bobbed-hair version of Nyssa.

Dialogue.Line: Ann Talbot, my fiancée, this is Nyssa.
And this is the Doctor, and Tegan and Adric.
Worcester. Have you an Uncle Percy?
Could there be Talbots near Esher?
Not possible. The hunt isn't good enough.
Well, Doctor, what can I offer you? Brewster here can make absolutely anything quite superbly.
Well, I do have a terrible thirst. Perhaps a lemonade with lots of ice.
The same as the Doctor, please.
Thank you. I'll have the same.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor coughs.

Dialogue.Line: Better make that orange juice for the children, Brewster.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan goes over to a small glass terrarium containing what appears to be a black orchid.

Dialogue.Line: Well, it's very charming of you to make us so welcome.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man upstairs has managed to untie himself. Brewster serves the drinks.

Dialogue.Line: I don't even know where Esher is.
The black orchid. Yes, it is beautiful. It was found on the Orinoco by my eldest son, George.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The portrait on the wall looks more like Charles to me.

Dialogue.Line: Of course. I thought I recognised the name. George Cranleigh the botanist, the explorer.
But the Brazilian forests took their toll. He never returned from his last expedition two years ago.
Ann was engaged to him, but I'm delighted to say that we're still going to have her in the family.
If Charles marries the right girl.
Nyssa doesn't even know where Esher is.
Which shows great taste. I'm sorry, Nyssa. Our curiosity has been vulgar enough. It's high time we all change.
Yes, well, I'm ready for a bath, so if the ladies will excuse us, I'll show you to your room, Doctor. Bring your drink. (to Adric) You too, old boy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Upstairs, the Amazonian enters the room and sees the empty bed. Then he is hit over the head with a poker and his charge leaves.
The Doctor holds up a Harlequin costume.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I must flatter myself. Call that an admirable choice.
It certainly is. What are you going to wear?
Ah, that's better left as a surprise, I think. Now then, I'd better attend to that young man. What was his name again?
I never could remember all those funny Baltic bits. Geography was never my strong point. My brother stole all the thunder there. Positive Odin. Till later, then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charles leaves. The Doctor tries on the harlequin mask, which covers his entire head.
Tegan's costume is a pink handkerchief skirt and green bodice. Very like Cicely Mary Barker's Sweet Pea Fairy.

Dialogue.Line: You know the dances of this period?
Well, I know the Charleston. I learned it for a play when I was at school.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan demonstrates.

Dialogue.Line: No, it's just that on Traken our dancing is much more formalised, and far more complex.
It's part of my training. And although I say it myself, I'm considered quite good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a knock at the door.
Ann enters, in a floaty purple dress with sequined blue butterfly bustier, followed by a maid with a box.

Dialogue.Line: My dears, I've had an absolutely ripping idea.
My dear, I'm so glad you think so. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She produces a second, identical dress.

Dialogue.Line: There. With the headdress nobody, but nobody, will be able to tell us apart. Isn't that topping?
Just as long as I don't show this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann moves her left strap to reveal -

Dialogue.Line: Yes. You haven't got one, have you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lays out his costume then goes into his en-suite bathroom and runs the bath. A secret door in the panelling opens and the mystery man comes in. He turns when the Doctor sings.

Dialogue.Line: I want to be happy, but I can't be happy, till I make you

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door slams.
He comes in from the bathroom.

He spots the open wall panel and goes inside. The door slams behind him and refuses to budge, so he sets off down the secret passageway. Meanwhile, the mystery man, with swollen hands, re-enters and gathers up the costume.

Music is provided by a gramophone, and food is on a buffet table. Brewster shows Lady Cranleigh the smoked salmon. She is dressed possibly as Marie Antoinette. Tall white wig, anyway. The partygoers are bravely ignoring the very strong wind threatening to blow everything away.

Other guests are dressed as Henry the Eighth, a Jane Austen period woman, a Turk, Cavalier lady. Sir Robert is bewigged as possibly Samuel Pepys and is dancing with Tegan. No idea what Adric is meant to be in his large collared top. Nyssa's headdress covers the top half of her face with sequins and has butterfly antennae.

Dialogue.Line: I rather think this will be fun. I think you have to ask me to dance.
Because that's what everybody else is doing.
Not me, you idiot. Each other. Come on, ask me.
I don't think I could do it.
Yes, you can. Just follow me. Come on.
I hope Lord Cranleigh's dancing with the right girl. It's a little naughty, really.
I think it's a great hoot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lord Cranleigh is in full hunting pink, and dancing with Ann.

Dialogue.Line: There is one way of not getting you mixed up.
By having every dance with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The music stops. Nyssa jumps onto the parapet and waves at Ann, who runs over to join her. Everyone watches the 'twins' do a little dance before Nyssa whispers in Ann's ear.

Dialogue.Line: Why do I always let my curiosity get the better of me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann and Nyssa run into the house, then come out again and curtsey. Which is which? Another record is put on the gramophone player. The girls split up. One goes over to Adric for a dance, the other to Charles.

Dialogue.Line: I might have known they were up to something. Now no one can tell them apart.
You should ask Lady Cranleigh to dance.
Well, look, I'm not really very good at it. Anyway, I'd much rather eat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric leaves her and goes for food. _A man dressed as King Charles approaches..

Dialogue.Line: Why didn't I leave after the cricket?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Latoni walks out onto the terrace. Lady Cranleigh is dancing with a royal Herald.

Dialogue.Line: You'll have to excuse me for a moment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She walks with Latoni past Adric at the buffet table and out of earshot.

Dialogue.Line: Latoni, what are you doing here? Get back to your quarters at once.
He hit me from behind and escaped.
I don't know. I have not seen him today.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The record finishes, and Charles has both butterfly girls in front of him.

Dialogue.Line: I've got every chance of having all...

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He manages to open a secret panel that opens into a corridor.

A clock can be heard ticking. The Doctor opens the next door to find a cupboard full of books. He picks up A Textbook of Botany for Students by Amy F M Johnson, B.Sc. The next door reveals a man's clothes.

Dialogue.Line: You deserve a better dancer than me, my dear. I must find you someone your own age.
But you're a beaut dancer, Sir Robert.
Beaut? That, I think, is a great hoot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: New music starts.
Tegan gets up and dances on her own in front of Sir Charles, both girls and Adric, who is eating as if tomorrow brings famine.
Little Bo Peep drags him away.
Then King Charles grabs one of the girls again.
And she does. The dance finishes, and Harlequin walks down the staircase and onto the terrace. Silently, he asks Nyssa or Ann for a dance.
The Doctor finds another secret panel, that opens to reveal a staircase going upwards.
He goes up to the attic room.
He picks up a book from the desk.
As Harlequin dances Ann, into the house, the Doctor returns to the corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Well, one of these must get me out of here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another cupboard door, then another. But this one contains the body of the man with the white jacket.
The Doctor finishes examining the body in the cupboard. The missing Digby, we presume. He then shuts the door on him and goes back to the secret entrance to the attic staircase. It slams behind him.

Dialogue.Line: This is Dittar Latoni, an old friend from Brazil.
Oh, but there is. You see, in my meanderings I've come across something rather unpleasant.
A dead man in a cupboard.
I'm afraid it's true. May I show you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks for the opening mechanism.

Dialogue.Line: Ten bedrooms and four receptions have access to this area.
A larger than average priest hole.
The Cranleighs of the time were devout and very hospitable. The priesthood came here from all over the country.
It's in here. Are you sure you want to look?
It's all right, Doctor. I'm made of quite stern stuff.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the cupboard door.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, he's one of the servants. Please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor shuts the door again.

Dialogue.Line: I'm very sorry, Doctor, that you've had this dreadful experience. I wonder, would you be kind enough to help me keep it from my other guests? I wouldn't want to upset them.
There's no point in involving them, unless the police decide otherwise.
Now, if you could tell me how to get back to my room, I think it's about time I got changed.

Yes, I'll show you. (The harlequin costume and mask are returned to the Doctor's room by someone with swollen fingers and wearing an argyle sweater. He leaves by the secret door _just before the Doctor enters.)_
I wonder where the Doctor is? MUIR: Well, it could be a number of these fellows, since he wishes to remain incognito. Not being bored by this old codger, are you? TEGAN: Of course not, Sir Robert.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On a bed, Ann stirs. We know it is her because her headdress is off, revealing her bobbed hair. The disfigured man leans over her and gently replaces the quilt.
The Doctor finishes his costume with the full face mask and looks in the cheval mirror.
Lady Cranleigh and Latoni discover that the door is locked. Ann wakes, gets out of the bed and runs for the door, terrified, while the man cowers in the corner by the bed.
Ann unlocks the door and runs into the arms of Lady Cranleigh. Latoni goes into the room.

Dialogue.Line: I had such an awful dream. My head's throbbing.
Oh, there, there, my dear. There, there.
How did I get here? I hurt my head. There was someone in fancy dress.
Try to put the whole incident out of your mind.
I can't. It was too awful.
Come on. Some brandy will help calm you down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the attic room, Latoni takes a coil of rope from a chest of drawers.
Adric is still demolishing the contents of the buffet table.

Dialogue.Line: Er, no thank you. This will do to be going along with.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Brewster goes along the table to a footman.

Dialogue.Line: Where's James with that bucket? Hurry him up will you, Henry?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another dance record ends.
Henry reports back to Brewster as Nyssa and Charles go to the buffet table.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I didn't have any breakfast.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan goes inside the house for a moment.
They mutter about the various dishes available, then Brewster whispers to them. Charles and Muir leave with Brewster. Tegan returns.
Charles and Sir Robert examine the dead footman.

Dialogue.Line: By the look of him, it couldn't have happened in a fall.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann's mask is on the floor. Muir picks it up.

Dialogue.Line: No, no, that was the other one out there on the terrace. Something's happened to Ann.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Muir takes off his full-bottomed wig.
The Doctor comes down the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid it's a little more serious than that, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lady Cranleigh and Ann come down the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: That's him! That's who attacked me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes off his mask.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, you. And he did that. I saw him.
I'm afraid Miss Talbot is mistaken. I've just this minute come down the stairs.
I am not mistaken! He danced with me and then pulled me in here. I shouted for help, James came and he killed him.
Sir Robert! Arrest that man. He killed James. I saw him.
No, Madge. Wait until the Sergeant gets here.
I suggest, Charles, that you call it a day. Tell your guests there's been an accident and ask them to go home.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charles leaves.

Dialogue.Line: This man attacked me and then killed James.
Oh, no, no, no, no, no.
You did! He did. He danced with me on the terrace, brought me in here and then he
Miss Talbot is quite mistaken. I have just come down these stairs. Before that, I was. Wait a minute. Was I like this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He holds the mask in front of this face.

Dialogue.Line: A completely logical explanation. A duplication of fancy dress. Someone else must be wearing an identical costume.
What about your own costume? There are two of those.
My little joke, Sir Robert. I was in charge of the costumes. There was only one harlequin. That one.
And only one murderer. Lady Cranleigh, I agreed to keep it from your guests, but I have the distinct feeling I'm in rather hot water.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lady Cranleigh looks to the ceiling.

Dialogue.Line: Why would I attack you? Have you done me any harm?
No, then I've no reason to harm you. And besides
I respect the sentiment, sir, but I have known Miss Talbot all her life. She has laid a complaint.
Made an accusation. There's more to this than meets the eye. Is this the reason that you wish to remain incognito?
Have you any means of identification?
Fortunate man. Just exactly who are you and what are you doing here?
I'm afraid if I told you, you wouldn't believe me.
I am the Chief Constable of this county and you, sir, are under suspicion of murder.
I travel in time and space. I have a time machine. You've read H G Wells?
I know of him, of course, yes. He writes fiction.
How can Lady Cranleigh help you?
There's something terribly wrong here. Lady Cranleigh knows. I showed her another dead body.
I'm afraid like Mister Well, the Doctor has a vivid imagination.
I showed you a body in a cupboard up there. You and the Indian.
An Indian, with a lip. I give up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sir Robert go up the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: Go and find Charles, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lady Cranleigh goes up the stairs.
Ann runs to Charles.

Dialogue.Line: I don't believe it. The Doctor would never do a thing like that.
We can all speak for him.
That's enough. You'd better get inside the house. The police will be here any minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric, Tegan and Nyssa leave.

Dialogue.Line: There's a telephone call for you, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leads the way out of the secret passage into the priest annex.
Sir Robert opens the cupboard. Where Digby once was, there is now a china doll.

Dialogue.Line: My father gave me that when I was six.
Where's the Indian? There was an Indian. I showed you the body of a man in there. A man of about thirty, in a white coat. A short white coat. You said he was a servant.
Well, not in there, no. With Lady Cranleigh. A South American native.
Lady Cranleigh, I appeal to you. It was you who introduced me to this man.
Yes. His name was Ditoni, or something like that. You said he was a friend from Brazil.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, up in the attic room, the disfigured man watches Latoni reading the Portuguese book.
Lord Cranleigh takes the telephone call that Brewster told him about.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? Cranleigh here. Smutty! Now listen, that fellow you sent us. What? What? Well, there was a fellow here. Yes. Won the blessed game for us. First class bat and a demon bowler.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Upstairs, the man tries to get his hands free. Sir Robert Muir has got the entire Tardis crew seated in the drawing room which opens directly onto the hall.

Dialogue.Line: You refuse to name yourself or give any good account of yourself except some irresponsible fiction, and you were seen to kill a man. Heaven knows what your motive was, but no doubt that will come out during the course of the enquiries.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charles and Ann enter with the local constabulary. Both of them.

Dialogue.Line: Bob, I've just received a telephone call from Smutty Thomas, apologising for the fact that the replacement he arranged missed his train.
Then this man is an imposter as well.
I don't know what this is all about, but I do know that the Doctor is no imposter.
I've just received a telephone call from
All right, Charles. I'm arresting this man, Sergeant, on suspicion of murder.
I must warn you that anything you say will be taken down and may be used in evidence.
I shall prefer the charge later at the Station, Sergeant.
Well, perhaps I should say accessories.
Accessories to murder. And they suffer the same penalty.
Right, you'd better all come along with me, then.
Thank you, Lady Cranleigh, for a delightfully unexpected afternoon.
Why don't you show them the Tardis, Doctor?
Sergeant, do we pass the station?
Would you stop there a moment?
There's vital evidence that will prove what I'm saying is true.
There's something I'd like to show you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The platform is devoid of obstructions.

Dialogue.Line: What I wanted to show you.
Come along, Markham. He's wasting time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the attic room, the man starts to untie his ankles.
Constable Cummings rushes out.

Dialogue.Line: The police box in the yard.
It was on the north bound platform at the railway station. We've been able to move it, but we can't break in. No key will unlock it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the disfigured man gets quietly off the bed, downstairs -

Dialogue.Line: No. It would do no good.
Do no good? We can't let that Doctor fellow suffer for something he hasn't done.
He will come to no harm. He is innocent.
We've got to tell the police.
Charles, please don't leave me alone.
Ann. Now there's something you've got to know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor unlocks the Tardis and opens the door.
Muir enters.

Dialogue.Line: But there won't be any room.
You are in for a surprise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Markham enters, followed by Tegan. The disfigured man jumps Latoni then stamps on his chest. Latoni manages to push the door key between the floor boards before he is strangled.
Unable to find the key, the disfigured man puts newspaper at the bottom of the door and sets fire to it.

Dialogue.Line: I must say, all this is going to be rather difficult to explain in my report. In this sense, you are owed an apology.
Well, there is still a murder to be explained.
A call from Lord Cranleigh, sir, up at the Hall. He's found another body. A man called Digby. His neck's broken, just like the servant, James.
I could get you there sooner.
You could? All right, you do that.
How could you? Oh, how could you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann runs out of the drawing room as the Tardis lands on the back lawn.
Ann rushes out of the house.
Upstairs, the fire has taken hold of the door. The disfigured man uses a fire-iron to smash at the planks and leaps through.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Mother, don't worry. I'll look after Ann.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The disfigured man runs into the entrance hall.

Dialogue.Line: All right, old chap. All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis crew and the police enter behind him. He is trapped by the staircase, where smoke is drifting down. Suddenly he elbows the Doctor and grabs -
The man pulls Nyssa up the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: He's started a fire! Get the Brigade!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man picks up Nyssa and runs upstairs with her as she screams. The Doctor, Adric and Lord Charles try to follow.

Dialogue.Line: Tell him, Lady Cranleigh, and why he's so interested in Ann.
They were engaged to be married. That thing, as you call him, was my elder son George.
The black orchid for one, Latoni for another.
I'll leave Lady Cranleigh to do that. I have to rescue Nyssa.
He won't hurt her. He loves Ann.
Really. And what will he do when he discovers he has the wrong girl?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A head appears above the parapet.

Dialogue.Line: Try and hold his attention here. I'll find a way up through the house.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs off. Charles takes off his jacket and starts to climb up the outside. Muir holds Adric back.
Muir takes Lady Cranleigh to one side.

Dialogue.Line: I've done something terribly wrong, Robert. Charles is not to blame.
What did the Doctor mean about the black orchid?

Well, you saw how George looked. The Kojabe Indians did that to him. To them, the black orchid is sacred. And they cut out his tongue. His mind was affected. He was rescued by another tribe, and their chief befriended him and brought him home.
Yes. With Latoni and Digby's help I was able to keep George hidden in the house.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Charles clambers over the parapet onto the roof.

Dialogue.Line: George. Please, George. Now George, she's done you no harm.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has also made it to the roof and is coming up from behind George and Nyssa.
George turns and sees the Doctor. Charles tries to grab him but is knocked down.

Dialogue.Line: George, that isn't Ann. Ann is down there. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: George looks over the edge and sees Ann. Nyssa tries to wriggle free.

Dialogue.Line: Keep still, Nyssa! It's true, George. Please let me have her. Please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: George gives Nyssa to the Doctor.
Charles steps forward to hug his brother. George backs away and tumbles over the parapet to land with a thud on the terrace.

Dialogue.Line: I'm grateful you stayed for the funeral.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan is holding a very large box.

Dialogue.Line: Our fancy dress. Do you really mean it? We can keep them?
There's something I'd like you to have.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She gives the Doctor a book.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you. I shall treasure it.
